instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3330: What is 820-3330? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.3V3_S5: What is 3V3_S5? 3V3_S5 and PP3V3_S5 are interchangeable, see definition for PP3V3_S5. .
definitions.PPVRTC_G3H: What is PPVRTC_G3H? PPVRTC_G3H is a 3.3v power rail for the RTC circuit present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state. .
definitions.PP3V3_SUS: What is PP3V3_SUS? The "PP3V3_SUS" rail on a MacBook logic board is a power rail that provides a 3.3-volt supply to the suspend-to-RAM (S3 state) components. .
definitions.PM_SLP_S5_L: What is PM_SLP_S5_L? PM_SLP_S5_L is a signal that, when 3.3v, turns on power rails that will wake the system from an S5 state. This signal is a part of the power management system of the MacBook.  The \"PM\" prefix typically stands for \"Power Management,\" and the \"SLP\" is for \"Sleep.\" The \"S5\" denotes the specific sleep state, which is Suspend to Disk, and the \"_L\" suffix indicates that this is an active low signal..
definitions.PM_SLP_SUS_L:
What is PM_SLP_SUS_L? 
The "PM_SLP_SUS_L" signal in a MacBook is related to the power management of the device, specifically concerning the 'suspend to RAM' state or S3 state. It's an active-low signal that, when asserted (low voltage), indicates the system should enter or is in the S3 sleep state. .
definitions.PM_DSW_PWRGD: What is PM_DSW_PWRGD? The "PM_DSW_PWRGD" signal in a MacBook stands for "Deep Sleep Well Power Good” and is required for the machine to power on & post..
definitions.3V3_SUS: What is 3V3_SUS? 3V3_SUS is an abbreviation for PP3V3_SUS. These are interchangeable. The "PP3V3_SUS" rail on a MacBook logic board is a power rail that provides a 3.3-volt supply to the suspend-to-RAM (S3 state) components. .
definitions.5V_S5: What is 5V_S5? 5V_S5 is an abbreviation for “PP5V_S5” which is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 state. .
definitions.TPS51980: What is TPS51980? This is a power chip responsible for the PP3V3_S5,  PP5V_S5,  and PP5V_S3 power rails on many A1286 Macbook Pros,  A1297 Macbook Pros,  A1369 Macbook Airs,  A1466 Macbook Airs,  A1370 Macbook Airs,  and A1465 Macbook Airs.
definitions.SMC_ADAPTER_EN: What is SMC_ADAPTER_EN? SMC_ADAPTER_EN enables the machine to work off of the power adapter when the proper power adapter is attached. Attacching an 85w Macbook Pro 15” power adapter to a 13” Macbook that requires a 60w power adapter is ok, attaching a 45w Macbook Air power adapter to a 15” macbook Pro that needs an 85w power adapter will result in SMC_ADAPTER_EN missing. .
definitions.U7201: What is U7201? U7201 is responsible for the 3.3v and 5v power rails on many devices..
definitions.SMC_BATLOW_L: What is SMC_BATLOW_L? SMC_BATLOW_L refers to a power management signal that indicates a low battery condition. The "_L" suffix suggests that this is an active-low signal, meaning that it becomes low when the battery reaches a low voltage threshold..
definitions.BATLOW_L: What is BATLOW_L? This signal tells the system that the battery is low, when the signal is low. Anytime you see an “_L” after a signal, that means that the signal is present when it is a low voltage, typically 0 volts to 0.5 volts.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Green Light, No Power
threads.message:
Working on an <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> board that has green light, but no power. No liquid involved. Using genuine 85W charger.

- All main rails present (<SIGNAL>5V_S5</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL>, ppbus, 3v42)
- Nothing gets warm, no shorts detected.
- <SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL> present
- <SIGNAL>PM_DSW_PWRGD</SIGNAL> present
- <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_SUS_L</SIGNAL> present, but <SIGNAL>PP5V_SUS</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS</SIGNAL> both missing.

- <TRANSISTOR>Q7820</TRANSISTOR>: my gate (pin 3) is 3.3v, and my source (pin 4) is 3.34v, but my drain (pin 1) is 0v.
- <TRANSISTOR>Q7840</TRANSISTOR>: my gate (pin 3) is 4.92v, and my source (pin 4) is 5.02v, but my drain (pin 1) is 0v.

Are these two MOSFETs bad? My gate is lower than the source on both, but the drain on each is 0v. If I'm on the wrong track, please just let me know. Since I've got <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_SUS_L</SIGNAL>, but not <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL>, and I'm missing <SIGNAL>5V_SUS</SIGNAL>/<SIGNAL>3V3_SUS</SIGNAL>, I'd assume this is where my issue is.

Any help appreciated!

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Green Light, No Power
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Green Light, No Power
threads.message: VCORE isn't brought up until much later in the power-on sequence. I'm not even getting into S4 yet. :)

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Green Light, No Power
threads.message: Sorry [USER="515"]SMMRepair[/USER] Was half asleep and didn't drink any coffee yet when I made that comment. It is very possible that those fets are bad.. However, Something killed them. Bad controller most likely and the controller most likely took out all the fets in that circuit as well. Replace the <CHIP>TPS51980</CHIP> and replace the FETs in that circuit and see if it fixes it.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Green Light, No Power
threads.message:
No you don't just replace the 51980 and pray that fixes it. Diagnose FFS!!

<SIGNAL>SMC_ADAPTER_EN</SIGNAL> present?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Green Light, No Power
threads.message: Hey Duke, thanks. Yes, <SIGNAL>SMC_ADAPTER_EN</SIGNAL> is present and steady.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Green Light, No Power
threads.message: [USER="2"]dukefawks[/USER] Isn't it true that If the 51980 fails it can screw up the 3.3v and 5v FETS?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Green Light, No Power
threads.message:
yes its true, however since OP has <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL>, <CHIP>U7201</CHIP> probably isn't an issue just yet.

Since <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_SUS_L</SIGNAL> is present, have you checked if this translates into <SIGNAL>P5VSUS_EN</SIGNAL> ? If not whats <SIGNAL>SMC_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL> ?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Green Light, No Power
threads.message: <SIGNAL>BATLOW_L</SIGNAL> is probably not present. Does this board charge a battery? Does it power on from a charged battery?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Green Light, No Power
threads.message: Hey Duke, the board does not power from a charged battery, and it does not charge the battery. <SIGNAL>SMC_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL> is missing, yes.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Green Light, No Power
threads.message: SMC should be sending out <SIGNAL>SMC_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL>. Check Pull up <RESISTOR>R5040</RESISTOR>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Green Light, No Power
threads.message: <RESISTOR>R5040</RESISTOR> measuring out fine; 3.3v on pin 1, 0v on pin 2. Thinking this might be a bad SMC at this point?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Green Light, No Power
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Green Light, No Power
threads.message: Hey Duke, yeah PPBUS is solid at 12.58v.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Green Light, No Power
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Green Light, No Power
threads.message: OK, so I have an update: I replaced the SMC, and I now have <SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PP5V_SUS</SIGNAL>, as well as <SIGNAL>SMC_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL> (3.3v). I still have no fan spin, but my PCH does get warm (not hot), so I think I'm now missing another s0 rail (or my PCH is bad), but I'll do some more digging and update the thread in a bit.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Green Light, No Power
threads.message: OK, I'm stuck at a point again. Not having a proper block-diagram with progressions/orders of rails makes it very tough. I have <SIGNAL>3V3_SUS</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>5V_SUS</SIGNAL>, but no <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL>. I'm either missing something after 3v3/<SIGNAL>5V_SUS</SIGNAL> but before <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL>, or my PCH is bad. The PCH gets slightly warm when the board is powered, which makes me think it's getting told to turn on, but nothing after that. I'm not sure how to confirm this, however. Any ideas on what I should check next? Thanks again.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Green Light, No Power
threads.message: If pch is getting warm without slp s5 i do suspect a bad pch too

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Green Light, No Power
threads.message: OK, thanks, duke! Identifying a failed PCH is just as helpful in learning as fixing the board. I'll send this one off to my more-skilled partner to get the PCH replaced. Thanks, Duke!
